Title.evidence: Title: Carotid Occlusion Surgery Study: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: COSS was a parallel group, prospective, 1:1 randomised, open-label, blinded-adjudication trial.

Participants.evidence: Participants with angiographic confirmed complete ICA occlusion causing TIA or ischemic stroke within 120 days and hemodynamic cerebral ischemia (elevated OEF by PET) were randomised to surgical or medical treatment.

Intervention.evidence: The surgical group underwent STA-MCA cortical branch anastomosis.

Objective.evidence: The Carotid Occlusion Surgery Study (COSS) was conducted to determine if STA-MCA bypass, when added to best medical therapy, would reduce subsequent ipsilateral stroke in patients with complete ICA occlusion and elevated OEF.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of ipsilateral stroke over two years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted centrally, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 195 patients were randomised: 97 to surgery and 98 to medical therapy.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the intention-to-treat analysis, the two-year primary endpoint rates were 21.0% for the surgical group and 22.7% for the medical group (p=0.78).

Result_Outcome.evidence: the two-year primary endpoint rates were 21.0% for the surgical group and 22.7% for the medical group (p=0.78).

Harms.evidence: Fourteen (15%) of 93 surgical patients experienced an ipsilateral hemispheric stroke within 30 days post-operation, with 12 occurring within two days.
